author: Sy O'Neill
title: Regent offers 128-day voyage to 6 continents, 31 countries, 62...
text:
The cruise world has been abuzz about a once-in-a-lifetime cruise being offered by luxury line Regent Seven Seas Cruises.
Board the Seven Seas Navigator in Miami on Jan. 5, 2017 — after a bon voyage gala at the Biltmore Hotel on the eve of embarkation — and sail around the world for 128 days. Visit six continents, 31 countries and 62 ports of call.
Rodolfo Gonzalez Norman Mineta, who served as Secretary of Transportation for both Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush, will be sailing on Crystal Symphony on the Nov. 28 Caribbean cruise. (Photo by Rodolfo Gonzalez/Austin American-Statesman) Three exclusive experiences are offered along the way at no additional cost: a Honolulu city tour and Kualoa Secret Island luncheon; the Dubai Sahara experience; and a Café de Paris gala dinner and casino visit in Monte Carlo.
Numerous other shore excursions are available to guests, including visits to a number of UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
The all-inclusive cruise also offers a long list of amenities, such as unlimited Wi-Fi; unlimited laundry, including dry cleaning and pressing; first class air; paid gratuities; and fine wines and spirits.
Attending the recent keel laying ceremony for Princess Cruises newest ship were (from left) Anthony Kaufman, senior vice president, Asia Operations, Princess Cruises; Attilio Dapelo, Fincantieri Shipyard director; and Cherry Wang, country director, Carnival China. The event included a Chinese lion dance ceremony to mark the construction milestone. The yet-to-be-named ship, debuting in 2017, will be customized to appeal to the China market. (Contributed by Carnival Corp.) The price tag for the World Cruise? Well, the $54,999 per person cabins are sold out, but the next category up is available at $56,999. It’s an oceanview room, no balcony!
For those who like the best staterooms on the ship, the master suites can be booked for $159,999 per person. That’s more than 1,000 square feet of space, one and a half bathrooms, a balcony — plus a personal butler and concierge-level services.
More details and the lengthy itinerary can be found at www.rssc.com . Look under Worldwide Destinations on the home page menu.
Former U.S. Sen. Bob Graham will be aboard Crystal Serenity for its Nov. 29 Mediterranean voyage. (Palm Beach Post staff photo) MORE BOATS TO CHINA: Carnival Corp. is sending two more of its ships to China next year.
Princess Cruises and Costa Cruises are each adding a new ship, bringing the company’s fleet of China-based ships to six.
Golden Princess will begin sailing out of Tianjin on a seasonal basis in 2016, with itineraries including destinations in northern Asia. Golden Princess joins the cruise line’s first China-based ship, Sapphire Princess, which has been homeported in Shanghai since 2014 and will start sailing year-round in China in 2016.
Regent Seven Seas will launch a 128-day World Cruise aboard the 490-guest Seven Seas Navigator on Jan. 5, 2017. The ship sails round trip from Miami. (Contributed by Regent Seven Seas Cruises) Costa Cruises will debut Costa Fortuna in April 2016 as its fourth ship based in China. Costa Fortuna joins Costa Serena, Costa Atlantica and Costa Victoria.
And there’s more on the horizon. The latest ship under construction for Princess Cruises will be based in Shanghai year-round when introduced in summer 2017. The ceremonial keel-laying for the as-yet-unnamed ship took place last month at the Fincantieri shipyard in Monfalcone, Italy.
GET UPDATED ON CURRENT EVENTS: Like to talk current events? Crystal Cruises’ Crystal Visions Enrichment Program is presenting interactive lectures and discussions with former U.S. senators, state and military leaders this fall. Included in the program are:
Former U.S. Sen. Scott Brown will lecture aboard Crystal Symphony, on the Nov. 14 Caribbean voyage. (Contributed by Crystal Cruises) Retired Gen. Anthony Zinni, a decorated 39-year U.S. military veteran who led troops in more than 70 countries. The author and diplomat will be aboard Crystal Serenity on the Oct. 18 and 25 Mediterranean voyages. Former U.S. Sen. Scott Brown, a retired Army colonel now working as a political correspondent. He will sail on Crystal Symphony, on the Nov. 14 Caribbean voyage. Former Sen. Alan Simpson and Norman Mineta, the secretary of transportation for both Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush. The pair will be sailing on Crystal Symphony on the Nov. 28 Caribbean cruise. Former Sen. Bob Graham, who also served as the 38th governor of Florida, now focuses on public service through his alma mater, the University of Florida. He will be on board Crystal Serenity, for the Nov. 29 Mediterranean voyage. Learn more about the cruise line at www.crystalcruises.com.
